S1381-1169(14)00218-0 10.1016/j.molcata.2014.05.021 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 XRD patterns of Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxide catalysts calcined at 500°C. Peaks (1) refer to Cr2O3 phase and (2) refer to ZrO2 phase. Fig. 2 FT-IR spectra of CZ0, CZ75 and CZ100 nanomaterials. Fig. 3 TEM images and EDS analysis of CZ0, CZ75 and CZ100 nanomaterials. Fig. 4 (A) Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and (B) pore size distribution of different prepared CZ nanomaterials. Fig. 5 Scheme of ethanol conversion on metal oxides. Fig. 6 (A) The total ethanol conversion (TC%), (B) the selectivity toward ethylene ( S C 2 H 4 % ) and (C) the selectivity toward acetaldehyde ( S CH 3 CHO % ) of different prepared CZ nanomaterials as a function of the reaction temperature Fig. 7 The reusability of CZ75 catalyst for the ethanol conversion at 350°C. Table 1 Physicochemical properties of Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxide catalysts calcined at 500°C. Catalyst Crystalline phase composition Average crystallite Size (nm) S BET (m2/g) S ext. Mahmoud ⁎ Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Education, Ain Shams University, Roxy, 11757 Cairo, Egypt Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Education, Ain Shams University Roxy Cairo 11757 Egypt ⁎ Tel.: +20 1003739822; fax: +20 2 22581243. Graphical abstract Novel Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxide catalysts (CZ) were successfully prepared by simple co-precipitation method. The as-prepared nanomaterials were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), energy dispersive spectroscopic (EDS) and N2 adsorption. The XRD analysis indicated the formation of amorphous materials of binary oxides, at higher ZrO2 content, which exhibited significantly modified textural characteristics, as indicated by N2 adsorption studies. The characteristics of the binary oxides were dependent on the Cr/Zr ratio. The composite with molar Zr/(Zr+Cr) ratio equals 75% (CZ75), in particular, exhibited significantly higher specific surface areas and porosity than other composites and pure oxides. The TEM images clearly illustrate how ZrO2 could control the particle size of Cr2O3 catalyst. The catalytic conversion of ethanol was studied at 200–400°C. The catalytic activities exhibited by the binary oxides were significantly higher than those of the pure oxides. The total ethanol conversion (TC%) and dehydration/dehydrogenation selectivity were dependent on the Cr/Zr ratio. A CZ75 nanomaterial, treated suitably, can be used as a reusable active catalyst in the ethanol conversion. Keywords Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxide catalysts Ethanol conversion Nanomaterials Reusability Porosity 1 Introduction Conversion of ethanol to hydrocarbons has received wide attention due to the heavy demand for hydrocarbons; such as ethylene, diethyl ether (DEE) and butadiene [1–3]. Catalytic transformation of alcohol into hydrocarbons is useful for petrochemical raw materials or as a motor fuel [1]. The decomposition of alcohols over metal oxide catalysts has been the subject of numerous studies due to its applicability to a variety of chemical synthesis processes [4–7]. In recent years, this subject has gained particular interest due to growing environmental, economic, and political concerns [5]. It is well known that ZrO2 possesses high thermal stability and durability at high temperatures. It was reported that zirconia suppressed the sintering of the active components when they were dispersed mutually [8,9]. Besides, chromium oxide (Cr2O3) is one of the most important transition metal oxides that are widely used in many industries. They include, but are not limited to: green pigments [10], hydrogen storage [11], gas sensors [12], coating, wear and corrosion resistance materials [13,14] and catalysts [15]. Moreover, chromia possesses interesting electrical, magnetic as well as surface properties that affect its usage as an industrial catalyst in many reactions. Such reactions include ethylene polymerization [16], propane oxidative dehydrogenation [17] and CO oxidation [18]. ZrO2-based solids and binary oxides catalysts are attracting a great deal of attention in recent years. Several ZrO2-based catalysts have been reported such as Co3O4/ZrO2 [19], Co–ZrO2/SiO2 [20], WO x /ZrO2 [21], CuO–ZrO2 [22], TiO2–ZrO2 [23], CeO2–ZrO2–CuO [24], NiO–MgO–ZrO2 [25] and Rh/ZrO2 [26]. Furthermore, these catalysts are active and selective in many important reactions such as CO preferential oxidation [19], Fischer–Tropsch synthesis [20], oxidative desulfurization [21], combustion of methane [22] and photocatalysis [23]. There are several reports concerning preparing ZrO2-based solids and binary oxides catalysts [19–26]. However, the preparation of Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxide catalysts was not studied. The purpose of this work is to prepare Cr2O3–ZrO2 nanomaterials. Furthermore, the as-synthesized nanomaterials were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), energy dispersive spectroscopic (EDS) and N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms. The ethanol conversion and catalyst reusability were investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Chromium (III) nitrate nonahydrate (Cr(NO3)3·9H2O, Oxford), zirconium (IV) oxychloride hydrate (ZrOCl2·8H2O, Oxford), ammonia solution (NH4OH, Alpha) and ethanol (absolute) (for HPLC, ≥99%) were used as received. Bi-distilled water was used for the preparation of all the catalysts. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxide catalysts were prepared by a co-precipitation method. In a typical experiment, the required quantities of Cr(NO3)3·9H2O and ZrOCl2·8H2O were dissolved separately in bi-distilled water and mixed together at 60°C. The aqueous solution of metal salts with a total cation concentration of 1.0M was contacted with a basic solution of aqueous ammonium of 2.0M dropwise with constant stirring until pH 9. The precipitate formed was aged in the mother liquid overnight, then filtered, washed with bi-distilled water several times until free from anion impurities. The obtained hydroxide precipitate was oven dried at 110°C for 8h and finally calcined at 500°C for 3h. The molar ratios of Zr in the composition were set for 0%, 25%, 50%, 75% and 100%. The formula CZ− x will be used throughout the paper to represent the different composites where x refers to the molar % Zr content, Zr/(Zr+Cr)×100. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction powder patterns were recorded at room temperature on a Philips Xpert powder diffractometer, using the Bragg–Brentano configuration and the CuKα, radiation λ =1.5406Å. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was recorded on a Jasco IR 4100 spectrometer (Japan) using KBr pellets. The morphology of the catalysts was observed by transmission electron microscope (TEM) equipped with energy dispersive spectroscopic (EDS) microanalysis system (JEM-2100CX (JEOL). The surface characteristics of the prepared catalysts were obtained using nitrogen gas adsorption at 77K on a Quantochrome AS1Win™-automated gas-sorption apparatus (USA). Before each N2 sorption measurement, samples were degassed at 200°C for 2h. 2.4 Catalytic activity test Catalytic activity tests of the prepared catalysts were determined by using ethanol conversion reaction at different temperatures varying between 200 and 400°C, the catalytic reaction was conducted in a flow reactor under atmospheric pressure. Thus, a 100mg catalyst sample was held between two glass wool plugs in a Pyrex glass reactor tube 20cm long and 1cm internal diameter packed with quartz fragments 2–3mm length. The temperature of the catalyst bed was regulated and controlled within ±1°C. Argon gas was used as the diluent and the ethanol vapor was introduced into the reactor through an evaporator/saturator at the ethanol pressure equal 100Torr. The flow rate of the argon was maintained at 30ml/min. Before carrying out such catalytic activity measurements each catalyst sample was activated by heating at 300°C in a current of argon for 1h then cooled to the catalytic reaction temperature. The injection time of the sample products and the unreacted ethanol was fixed after 15min, and many injections were carried out to give constant conversion. The reaction products in the gaseous phase were analyzed chromatographically using Perkin–Elmer Auto System XL Gas Chromatograph fitted with a flame ionization detector. The column used was stainless steel chromatographic columns, 4m length, packed with 10% squalane supported on chromosorb. The reaction products were analyzed at a column temperature of 60°C in all conversion runs. Detector temperature was kept at 250°C. 2.5 Catalyst reusability To study the reusability of catalyst, after each ethanol conversion experiment, the used catalyst was regenerated at 300°C in a current of argon for 1h. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD analysis XRD is used for identification of the crystal phase and crystallite size of each phase present. XRD patterns of Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxide catalysts calcined at 500°C are shown in Fig. 1 . For CZ0 and CZ25 nanomaterials, only had the characteristic peaks of the crystallized α-Cr2O3 phase (Eskolaite) (JCPDS No. 38-1479). At lower ZrO2 content, i.e.CZ25 nanomaterial, there are no diffraction peaks of the crystalline ZrO2 phase in the XRD pattern, implying that ZrO2 in this sample exists in a highly dispersed state on Cr2O3 surface. At higher ZrO2 content, i.e. CZ50 and CZ75 patterns, no characteristic peaks were visible, indicating that they were amorphous materials. Several studies have reported that zirconia-based binary metal oxides at higher ZrO2 content calcined at 500°C were an amorphous material [27,28]. It has been reported that ZrO2 may inhibit the formation of well crystalline particles, i.e., binary oxides mostly exist in the form of microcrystals [29,30]. The peaks in the pattern of CZ100 nanomaterial could be assigned only to the presence of both monoclinic and tetragonal ZrO2 phases (JCPDS No. 37-0031) [31]. It is well known that pure ZrO2 has two coexisting structurally stable phases, namely m-ZrO2 and t-ZrO2. The 2θ of 24.1°, 28.2°, 31.4°, and 34.1° are assigned to the m-ZrO2, and the peaks centered at about 35.2°, 50.2°, and 60.3° are assigned to the t-ZrO2 [32,33]. For CZ0, CZ25 and CZ100 nanomaterials, the crystallite sizes were estimated using the Scherrer equation [34] and the results are listed in Table 1 . As shown in Table 1, increasing the ZrO2 content from 0 to 100mol% led to a significantly decreased the crystallite size. 3.2 FT-IR analysis Fig. 2 shows the FT-IR spectra of CZ0, CZ75 and CZ100 binary oxide catalysts. The broad absorption peak at 3600–3200cm−1 can be attributed to the hydroxyl groups of hydrated oxide surface and the adsorbed water. All spectra exhibited in the (υOH) region one band with a maximum around 3446cm−1, which characterizes the stretching vibrations of surface hydroxyl groups [35]. The bands observed at 1640–1630cm−1 can be assigned to the molecular water bending mode [36]. The bands around 1100cm−1 can be attributed to MOH stretching vibrations [37]. The bands at 1460–1400cm−l corresponded to the MOM deformation vibrations [38]. The bands at 420cm−1 corresponded to MO stretching vibrations [38]. On the other hand, in the FT-IR spectra of CZ0 nanomaterial, the vibration band at 568cm−1 characterizes the CrO distortion vibration and the band at 622cm−1 identifies the chromium oxide as the α-Cr2O3 phase (Eskolaite) [39,40]. FT-IR results show good coincidence with XRD analysis and indicate the successful production of pure α-Cr2O3 nanomaterial. 3.3 TEM characterization Fig. 3 shows the TEM images of Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxide catalysts. The aggregates of uniform spherical nanoparticles with average diameter 23nm were observed in CZ0 nanomaterial. Similarly, a small aggregate uniform spherical nanoparticles with average diameter 9nm was obtained for the CZ100 nanoparticle. Furthermore, the CZ75 binary oxide catalyst possesses very small aggregate uniform spherical nanoparticles with average diameter 4nm. The TEM images clearly illustrate how ZrO2 could control the particle size of Cr2O3 catalyst [30]. The morphology change from large blocks into small particles resulted in the formation of more interpores between the small particles. This was also confirmed by the N2 adsorption results. The compositions of all the local spots in the CZ75 catalyst were almost the same and consistent with the field average. These results suggested that zirconium and Chromium are uniformly dispersed in the CZ75 catalyst. The average particle size calculated from the TEM micrographs is consistent with the average crystallite size obtained from XRD measurement. To investigate the elemental composition of CZ binary oxide catalysts, energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) analysis was carried out. The EDS results of the prepared nanomaterials prove the presence of chromium, zirconium and oxygen elements as shown in Fig. 3. The analytical results from EDS are virtually identical or very close to the nominal wt% of Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxide catalysts. 3.4 Surface area and porosity Fig. 4(A) and (B) shows the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and the pore size distribution of Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxide catalysts, respectively. The isotherms of CZ0 and CZ25 nanomaterials could be classified as a typical type II according to the IUPAC classification [41], which was typical of either nonporous or mixed pore system. However, the isotherms of CZ50 and CZ75 nanomaterials were the type I, indicating the pore structure of CZ50 and CZ75 were micropore. Furthermore, the isotherm of CZ100 nanomaterial was the type IV, which was typical of mesoporous material. The pore size distribution calculated by the BJH method from the desorption branch of the isotherm. Table 1 lists the most important textural parameters calculated from the isotherms for the prepared nanomaterials. Table 1 presents the specific surface areas of the CZ nanomaterials. Interestingly, the specific surface areas of the binary oxides were significantly higher than those of the pure oxides. The highest specific surface areas were observed for the catalysts with higher ZrO2 content, CZ50 and CZ75. The catalyst with lower ZrO2 content, CZ25, showed, relatively, medium surface area that was comparable with this of Cr2O3. While the pure oxides, CZ0 and CZ100, showed significantly lower surface areas. Thus, the addition of ZrO2 to Cr2O3 catalyst resulted in an enhancement of its specific surface area. The average values of pore radius (ŕ) appear similar for all samples and not much higher than 8.3nm, indicating that most porosity in these samples is due to very small cavities, with size near the boundary of micro and mesopores. The pore size distribution of CZ0, Fig. 4(B), shows a multimodal distributions with an average pore diameter of 4.7nm. However, the pore size distribution of CZ25 shows a relatively narrow distribution in the micro and low mesoporous range with an average pore diameter of 4.8nm. Furthermore, the pore size distribution of CZ50 and CZ75 show a very narrow distribution in the microporous range with an average pore diameter of 2.2nm. In addition, the pore size distribution of CZ100 shows a good homogeneity of the mesopore structure with an average pore diameter of 6.2nm. The average pore radius (ŕ) is close to average pore diameter. Therefore, the loading of ZrO2 decreased the average pore diameter of Cr2O3 nanomaterial. The results of the textural characterization are in agreement with the XRD and the TEM results discussed earlier. On the other hand, the textural characteristics of CZ50 and CZ75 support the suggestion of possible dispersion of the zirconium ions in the chromium oxide matrix. These results indicate that the addition of ZrO2 to Cr2O3 greatly modify its textural properties. The significantly high specific surface area and the unique pore characteristics of Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxides compared with the corresponding pure oxides are expected to enhance their catalytic potential. 3.5 Catalytic activity 3.5.1 Ethanol conversion on Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxide catalysts The catalytic conversion of ethanol within the temperature range 200–400°C over Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxide catalysts led to the formation of ethylene and diethyl ether via dehydration and acetaldehyde via dehydrogenation on what can be classified as acid sites and basic or redox sites, respectively, as summarized in Fig. 5 . The main products were the ethylene and acetaldehyde. In addition, some trace amounts of diethyl ether (less than 10%) are found at temperatures up to 250°C. The total ethanol conversion (TC%) of all catalysts as a function of the reaction temperature is showed in Fig. 6(A). The CZ75 nanomaterial being the most active while the CZ0 being the less active one. The total conversion (TC%) of all catalysts remarkably increased as reaction temperature rose from 200 to 400°C. The overall catalytic activities exhibited by the binary oxides were significantly higher than those of the pure oxides as shown by the total conversion in Fig. 6(A). In other words, the CZ0 and CZ100 nanomaterials showed total conversions of ∼19.7% and ∼55.8% at 350°C, while the CZ25, CZ50 and CZ75 showed conversions around 70.3%, 63.2% and 76.5%, respectively. So, the obtained changes in the catalytic activity of CZ catalysts, as a function of ZrO2 loading, were probably due to the reduction crystallite size of Cr2O3 phase [42]. Furthermore, the role of surface area and microporosity are important in the interpretation the high catalytic activity of binary oxide catalysts with comparison to the pure oxides [38]. The least active catalyst is the CZ0, which is present in the form of crystallites exhibiting small surface area. It may be supposed that the active phase contained in such crystallites is coming predominantly from their near-to-surface layers and participation of their bulk in the catalytic reaction is very much limited [43]. On the other hand, the most active catalyst, CZ75, is the one in which high surface area of binary oxide enables very strong dispersion of ZrO2 on Cr2O3 surface providing a higher number of active phases to participate in ethanol conversion. Finally, the loading of ZrO2 modified the catalytic behavior of Cr2O3 nanomaterial. 3.5.2 Ethanol dehydration/dehydrogenation selectivity on Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxide catalysts The selectivity toward ethylene ( S C 2 H 4 % ) and acetaldehyde ( S CH 3 CHO % ) is presented in Fig. 6(B) and (C), respectively. On the whole it can be stated that increasing the total conversion as well as the reaction temperature is accompanied by an increase in the dehydration selectivity (ethylene production) and a decrease in the dehydrogenation selectivity (acetaldehyde production). Clearly, the ethylene selectivity was in the order of CZ75>CZ100>CZ50>CZ25>CZ0. On the contrary, the acetaldehyde selectivity was in the order of CZ0>CZ25>CZ50>CZ75>CZ100. The higher dehydration activity of CZ75 catalyst compared to CZ0 one suggests a higher acidity of the former catalyst than the latter one. On the other hand, the higher dehydrogenation activity of CZ0 catalyst compared to CZ100 one suggests higher redox sites of the former catalyst than the latter one. Meanwhile, it can be roughly concluded, based on the current results, those CZ binary oxide catalysts with, generally, higher ZrO2 content are suitable for ethanol dehydration to ethylene, while catalysts with higher Cr2O3 content are more suitable for dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde. This points to a higher dehydration activity of CZ75 catalyst, probably related to a higher concentration of Lewis acid sites on the surface of ZrO2 [44]. It was reported that zirconia has acid–base characteristics (i.e. Lewis acidic center Zr4+ and basic center O2−) [26]. It is known that the oxygen atoms from the solid lattice typically behave as Lewis or Brønsted base centers, while the metal cations exhibit Lewis acidic or redox activity [45]. In other words, the addition of ZrO2 to Cr2O3 catalyst resulted in an improvement of its dehydration selectivity toward ethylene. As a result of doping ZrO2 with metal oxides, the obtained materials changed not only their crystallographic structure, but also in the materials there were a large number of oxygen vacancies (i.e. Lewis acidic centers) [45,46]. Moreover, it was reported that oxygen vacancies, which bring about the formation of Lewis acidic centers at the surfaces of the materials, are responsible for their catalytic properties [46]. On the other hand, some researches indicate that the active species for dehydrogenation on Cr2O3-based catalysts are Cr3+ ions [16,47,48]. It has been reported that when annealing takes place, in air, the chromia gel suffers the well-known oxidation–reduction cycle (Cr3+ →Cr6+ →Cr3+) and becoming a highly nonstoichiometric oxide [49]. The presence of chromium ions in various oxidation states enables an easy exchange of electrons between the oxide and the adsorbed species of the catalytic reactions, the oxide being in a position to accept electrons as well as to give them up [49]. 3.5.3 Reusability of catalyst The reusability of a catalyst is very important for commercial feasibility. The reusability of the CZ0, CZ25, CZ50, CZ75 and CZ100 nanomaterials for the ethanol conversion is shown in Table 2 . Fig. 7 shows the reusability of the total ethanol conversion of CZ75 catalyst at 350°C. It can be seen that for the first reuse, there was an observed decrease in the catalytic activity (TC%) of the CZ25, CZ50 and CZ100 catalysts while a slight increase for CZ0 catalyst. Also, the reusability of the CZ25, CZ50 and CZ100 catalysts showed high stability toward ethylene selectivity. Even though, the ethylene selectivity decreases sharply with CZ0 catalyst. On the other hand, the reusability of the CZ0, CZ25 and CZ50 catalysts showed high stability and increase toward acetaldehyde selectivity. Moreover, the acetaldehyde selectivity decreases sharply with CZ100 catalyst. Additionally, the reusability of the CZ75 catalyst for the ethanol conversion has been investigated for three successive runs after regeneration at 300°C in a current of argon for 1h. The total ethanol conversion and dehydration/dehydrogenation selectivity of the CZ75 catalyst after the three successive runs showed much high stability compared to a fresh catalyst as shown in Fig. 7 and Table 2. In other words, the catalytic activity (TC%) of the CZ75 nanomaterial at 350°C were quite stable even in third reuse (TCfresh =76.5%; TC1st reuse =76.5%; TC2nd reuse =76.5%; TC3rd reuse =71.3%). All these facts suggested the good reusability of the CZ nanomaterials in ethanol conversion. Furthermore, the reusability of the catalyst suggests that CZ75 is the most potential catalyst which can be applied in ethanol conversion. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, novel Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxide catalysts with different Cr/Zr ratios were successfully prepared by simple co-precipitation method. The binary oxides showed significantly modified textural characteristics as compared with the corresponding pure oxides, Cr2O3 and ZrO2. The characteristics of the binary oxides were dependent on the Cr/Zr ratio. The highest specific surface areas were observed for the composite with 75% Zr, CZ75, and also exhibited homogeneous pore size distribution in the microporous range. The catalytic activities exhibited by the binary oxides were significantly higher than those of the pure oxides. The total ethanol conversion (TC%) and dehydration/dehydrogenation selectivity were dependent on the Cr/Zr ratio. A CZ75 nanomaterial, treated suitably, can be used as a reusable active catalyst in the ethanol conversion. Acknowledgements I would like to thank Dr. M. Saif (Ain Shams University, Egypt) for using her lab facilities (Inorganic nanochemistry laboratory) and Dr. Aïcha Mbarek (Clermont Université, France and Université de Sfax, Tunisie) for the XRD measurement. coredata.dc:description: Novel Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxide catalysts (CZ) were successfully prepared by simple co-precipitation method. The as-prepared nanomaterials were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), energy dispersive spectroscopic (EDS) and N2 adsorption. The XRD analysis indicated the formation of amorphous materials of binary oxides, at higher ZrO2 content, which exhibited significantly modified textural characteristics, as indicated by N2 adsorption studies. The characteristics of the binary oxides were dependent on the Cr/Zr ratio. The composite with molar Zr/(Zr+Cr) ratio equals 75% (CZ75), in particular, exhibited significantly higher specific surface areas and porosity than other composites and pure oxides. The TEM images clearly illustrate how ZrO2 could control the particle size of Cr2O3 catalyst. The catalytic conversion of ethanol was studied at 200–400°C. The catalytic activities exhibited by the binary oxides were significantly higher than those of the pure oxides. The total ethanol conversion (TC%) and dehydration/dehydrogenation selectivity were dependent on the Cr/Zr ratio. A CZ75 nanomaterial, treated suitably, can be used as a reusable active catalyst in the ethanol conversion.
coredata.dc:title: Highly dispersed Cr2O3–ZrO2 binary oxide nanomaterials as novel catalysts for ethanol conversion
